key_recommendations.diagnosis: - First-line: IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) with total IgA - Consider IgA endomysial antibody (EMA) for confirmation if tTG weakly positive - Duodenal biopsy essential for diagnosis in adults - Children with tTG >10x ULN may avoid biopsy if EMA positive and symptomatic - HLA-DQ2/DQ8 useful to exclude CD (high negative predictive value)
key_recommendations.management: - Lifelong strict gluten-free diet - Specialist dietitian referral mandatory - Annual review recommended - Assess bone health at diagnosis - DEXA scan if appropriate - Screen for deficiencies: full blood count, ferritin, B12, folate, calcium, vitamin D - Pneumococcal vaccination (due to hyposplenism risk)
key_recommendations.nonresponsive_symptoms: - Commonest cause: inadvertent gluten ingestion - Alternative diagnoses: IBS, lactose intolerance, SIBO, microscopic colitis - Persistent villous atrophy despite GFD: consider refractory CD - Refractory CD: requires specialist gastroenterology input
key_recommendations.screening: - First-degree relatives: 10% risk - Type 1 diabetes, autoimmune thyroid disease, IgA deficiency - Unexplained iron deficiency, chronic diarrhea, weight loss
key_recommendations.complications: - Osteoporosis - Hyposplenism (increased infection risk) - Small bowel malignancy (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma) - rare but increased risk - Fertility issues may improve with GFD
